children.title: Battery calculated capacity in standby mode (hrs)
Battery calculated capacity in alarm mode (min)
Battery Mfr Date
children.hint: Enter Month/Year  Table 14.3.1(9(b))  Verify marking of the month/year of manufacture on each battery cell/unit.  Replace any cell/unit if alarm equipment manufacturer's replacement date has been exceeded.

children.title: Visual Inspection
children.hint: Table 14.3.1.9(1(a))  Ensure month and year of manufacture is marked in the m/y format on each battery unit.  Verify tightness of battery connections.  Inspect terminals for corrosion, excessive container/cover distortion, cracks in cell/unit or leakage of electrolyte.  Replace any battery cell/unit if corrosion, distortion, or leakage is observed.

children.title: Temperature test
children.hint: Table 14.4.3.2.9(1)  Upon initially opening the cabinet door, measure and record the temperature of each battery cell/unit at the negative terminal with an infrared thermometer.  Replace any battery cell/unit if the temperature is greater than 18 F(10 C).

children.title: Charger Test
children.hint: Table 14.4.3.2(9(2))  With the battery fully charged & connected to the charger, measure the voltage across the battery with a voltmeter.  Verify the voltage is within the battery/alarm equipment mfr's recommendations.  If the voltage is outside of the specified limits, either adjust the charger to within limits or replace the charger.

children.title: Voltage Test - Batt 1
children.hint: Table 14.4.3.2(9(3))  With the battery fully charged and connected to the charger, measure the voltage of each cell/unit with a voltmeter.  Replace the battery when any cell/unit measures a voltage less than 13.26 volts.

children.title: Voltage Test - Batt 2
children.hint: Table 14.4.3.2(9(3))  With the battery fully charged and connected to the charger, measure the voltage of each cell/unit with a voltmeter.  Replace the battery when any cell/unit measures a voltage less than 13.26 volts.

children.title: Ohmic Test - Batt 1
children.hint: Notes: g See A.14.4.3.2 Item 9(4). A load test is permitted in lieu of an ohmic test   Table 14.4.3.2(9(4))  With the battery fully charged and connected to the charger, measure the internal ohmic value of each battery cell/unit.  Record the test date and ohmic value on each cell/unit.  Replace the battery when the ohmic measurement of any cell/unit deviates from the established baseline by 30% or more for conductance and 40% or more for resistance or impedance.  Where the battery or test equipment manufacturer's baseline ohmic values are used, replace the battery when any cell/unit has an internal ohmic value outside of the acceptable range.

children.title: Ohmic Test - Batt 2
children.hint: Notes: g See A.14.4.3.2 Item 9(4). A load test is permitted in lieu of an ohmic test   Table 14.4.3.2(9(4))  With the battery fully charged and connected to the charger, measure the internal ohmic value of each battery cell/unit.  Record the test date and ohmic value on each cell/unit.  Replace the battery when the ohmic measurement of any cell/unit deviates from the established baseline by 30% or more for conductance and 40% or more for resistance or impedance.  Where the battery or test equipment manufacturer's baseline ohmic values are used, replace the battery when any cell/unit has an internal ohmic value outside of the acceptable range.

children.hint: Indicate location of docs 7.7.2.3  All record documentation shall be stored in the documentation cabinet.  No record documentation shall be stored in the control unit.

children.title: Lamps/LEDs function properly.
children.hint: Table 14.4.3.2(2(4))  Illuminate lamps and LEDs

children.title: Interfaced equipment signals verified.
children.hint: Table 14.4.3.2(2(3))  Verify integrity of single or multiple circuits providing interface between two or more control units.  Test interfaced equipment connections by operating or simulating operation of the equipment being supervised.  Verify signals required to be transmitted at the control unit

children.title: Transmission of signals to off-premises location.
children.hint: Table 14.4.3.2(3(4))  Actuate an initiating device and verify receipt of alarm signal at the off-premises location.  Create a trouble condition and verify receipt of a trouble signal at the off-premises location.  Actuate a supervisory device and verify receipt of a supervisory signal at the off-premises location.  If a transmission carrier is capable of operation under a single- or multiple-fault condition, actuate an initiating device during such fault condition and verify receipt of an alarm signal and a trouble signal at the off-premises location.

children.title: Ground fault monitoring circuit, if applicable,  operates properly.
children.hint: Table 14.4.3.2(3(3)) If the system has a ground detection feature, verify the occurrence of ground-fault indication whenever any installation conductor is grounded.

children.title: Power supply supervison operating properly.
children.hint: Table  14.4.3.2(2(1))  Verify correct receipt of alarm, supervisory, and trouble signals (inputs); operation of evacuation signals and auxiliary functions (outputs)'; circuit supervision, including detection of open circuits and ground faults; and power supply supervision for detection of loss of ac power and disconnection of secondary batteries.

children.title: Correct fuses installed.
children.hint: Table 14.4.3.2(2(2))  Verify rating and supervision.

children.title: Disconnect switches, if applicable, operating properly.
children.hint: Table 14.4.3.2(3(2))  If control unit has a disconnect or isolating switches, verify performance of intended function of each switch.  Verify receipt of trouble signal when a supervised function is disconnected.

children.title: Secondary (standby) power supply.
children.hint: Table 14.4.3.2(2(5))  Disconnect all secondary (standby) power and test under maximum load, including all alarm appliances requireing simultaneous operation.  Reconnect all secondary (standby) power at end of test.  Test redundant power supplies separately.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Visual Inspection
children.hint: Table 14.3.1(4(1))  Verify location, physical condition and a system normal condition.

children.title: Signal from initiating device received at supervising station.
children.hint: Table 14.4.3.2(4(2))  Test DACT for line seizure capability by initiating a signal while using the telephone line (primary line for DACTs using two telephone lines) for a telephone call. Ensure that the call is interrupted and that the communicator connects to the digital alarm receiver. Verify receipt of the correct signal at the supervising station.  Verify each transmission attempt is completed within 90 seconds from going off-hook to on-hook.  Disconnect the telephone line (primary line for DACTs using two telephone lines) from the DACT.   Verify indication of the DACT trouble signal occurs at the premises fire alarm control unit within 4 minutes of detection of the fault. Verify receipt of the telephone line trouble signal at the supervising station.   Restore the telephone line (primary line for DACTs using two telephone lines), reset the fire alarm control unit, and verify that the telephone line fault trouble signal returns to normal. Verify that the supervising station receives the restoral signal from the DACT.  Disconnect the secondary means of transmission from the DACT. Verify indication of the DACT trouble signal occurs at the premises fire alarm control unit within 4 minutes of detection of the fault. Verify receipt of the secondary means trouble signal at the supervising station. Restore the secondary means of transmission, reset the fire alarm control unit, and verify that the trouble signal returns to normal. Verify that the supervising station receives the restoral signal from the secondary transmitter.  Cause the DACT to transmit a signal to the DACR while a fault in the telephone line (number) (primary line for DACTs using two telephone lines) is simulated. Verify utilization of the secondary communication path by the DACT to complete the transmission to the DACR.

children.title: Line seizure test with receipt of signal at supervising station.

Cause a signal to be transmitted on each individual incoming DACR line (path) at least once every 6 hours (24 hours for DACTs installed prior to adoption of the 2013 edition of NFPA 72)  Verify receipt of these signals.

children.title: Receiver malfunction supervision.
children.hint: Table 14.4.3.2(27(3)) Cause the following conditions of all DARRs on all subsidiary and repeater station receiving equipment. Verify receipt at the supervising station of correct signals for each of the following conditions:  (1) AC power failure of the radio equipment  (2) Receiver malfunction  (3) Antenna and interconnecting cable failure  (4) Indication of automatic switchover of the DARR  (5) Data transmission line failure between the DARR and the supervising or subsidiary station.

children.title: Transmitter Operational Test
children.hint: Table 14.4.3.2(4(4))  Actuate initiating device. Verify production of not less than three complete rounds of not less than three signal impulses each by the McCulloh transmitter.  If end-to-end metallic continuity is present and with a balanced circuit, cause each of the following four transmission channel fault conditions in turn, and verify receipt of correct signals at the supervising station:   (1) Open  (2) Ground  (3) Wire-to-wire short  (4) Open and ground   If end-to-end metallic continuity is not present and with a properly balanced circuit, cause each of the following three transmission channel fault conditions in turn, and verify receipt of correct signals at the supervising station:   (1) Open  (2) Ground  (3) Wire-to-wire short

children.title: Evacuation signals verified.
children.hint: Table 14.4.3.2(30(1))  At a minimum, test control equipment to verify correct receipt of alarm, supervisory, and trouble signals (inputs); operation of evacuation signals and auxiliary functions (outputs); circuit supervision, including detection of open circuits and ground faults; and power supply supervision for detection of loss of ac power and disconnection of secondary batteries.

children.title: Interfaced equipment signals verified.
children.hint: Table 14.4.3.2(30(3))  Verify integrity of single or multiple circuits providing interface between two or more control units.  Test interfaced equipment connections by operating or simulating operation of the equipment being supervised.  Verify signals required to be transmitted at the control unit.

children.title: Transmission of signals verified.
children.hint: Table 14.4.3.2(30(1))  At a minimum, test control equipment to verify correct receipt of alarm, supervisory, and trouble signals (inputs); operation of evacuation signals and auxiliary functions (outputs); circuit supervision, including detection of open circuits and ground faults; and power supply supervision for detection of loss of ac power and disconnection of secondary batteries.

children.title: Ground fault monitoring circuit, if applicable,  operates properly.

children.title: Power supply supervison operating properly.

EVAC Control Unit and Power Devices
Battery manufacture date
children.hint: Enter Month/Year  Table 14.3.1(9(b))  Verify marking of the month/year of manufacture on each battery cell/unit.  Replace any cell/unit if alarm equipment manufacturer's replacement date has been exceeded.

children.title: Visual Inspection
children.hint: Table 14.3.1.9(1(a))  Ensure month and year of manufacture is marked in the m/y format on each battery unit.  Verify tightness of battery connections.  Inspect terminals for corrosion, excessive container/cover distortion, cracks in cell/unit or leakage of electrolyte.  Replace any battery cell/unit if corrosion, distortion, or leakage is observed.

children.title: Temperature test
children.hint: Table 14.4.3.2.9(1)  Upon initially opening the cabinet door, measure and record the temperature of each battery cell/unit at the negative terminal with an infrared thermometer.  Replace any battery cell/unit if the temperature is greater than 18 F(10 C).

children.title: Charger Test
children.hint: Table 14.4.3.2(9(2))  With the battery fully charged & connected to the charger, measure the voltage across the battery with a voltmeter.  Verify the voltage is within the battery/alarm equipment mfr's recommendations.  If the voltage is outside of the specified limits, either adjust the charger to within limits or replace the charger.

children.title: Voltage Test - Batt 1
children.hint: Table 14.4.3.2(9(3))  With the battery fully charged and connected to the charger, measure the voltage of each cell/unit with a voltmeter.  Replace the battery when any cell/unit measures a voltage less than 13.26 volts.

children.title: Voltage Test - Batt 2
children.hint: Table 14.4.3.2(9(3))  With the battery fully charged and connected to the charger, measure the voltage of each cell/unit with a voltmeter.  Replace the battery when any cell/unit measures a voltage less than 13.26 volts.

children.title: Ohmic Test - Batt 1
children.hint: Notes: g See A.14.4.3.2 Item 9(4). A load test is permitted in lieu of an ohmic test   Table 14.4.3.2(9(4))  With the battery fully charged and connected to the charger, measure the internal ohmic value of each battery cell/unit.  Record the test date and ohmic value on each cell/unit.  Replace the battery when the ohmic measurement of any cell/unit deviates from the established baseline by 30% or more for conductance and 40% or more for resistance or impedance.  Where the battery or test equipment manufacturer's baseline ohmic values are used, replace the battery when any cell/unit has an internal ohmic value outside of the acceptable range.

children.title: Ohmic Test - Batt 2
children.hint: Notes: g See A.14.4.3.2 Item 9(4). A load test is permitted in lieu of an ohmic test   Table 14.4.3.2(9(4))  With the battery fully charged and connected to the charger, measure the internal ohmic value of each battery cell/unit.  Record the test date and ohmic value on each cell/unit.  Replace the battery when the ohmic measurement of any cell/unit deviates from the established baseline by 30% or more for conductance and 40% or more for resistance or impedance.  Where the battery or test equipment manufacturer's baseline ohmic values are used, replace the battery when any cell/unit has an internal ohmic value outside of the acceptable range.

Location of central control point.
children.hint: Figure 7.8.2(k) 3.2 Area of Refuge  Indicate where the control point is located.

children.title: Area of Refuge signs posted at proper locations and illuminated.
children.hint: (NFPA 101 7.2.12.3.5.1) the sign required by 7.2.12.3.5 shall conform to the requirements of ICC/ANSI A117.1, for such signage and shall display the international symbol of accessibility. Signs also shall be located as follows: (1) At each door opening providing access to the area of refuge (2) At all exits not providing an accessible means of egress, as defined in 3.3.178.1  (3) Where necessary to indicate clearly the direction to an area of refuge. (7.2.12.3.5.2)  Signs required by 7.2.12.3.5 shall be illuminated as required for special signs in accordance with 7.10.8.1. (7.2.12.3.6)  Tactile signage complying with ICC/ANSI A11.71,  shall be located at each door opening to an area of refuge.

children.title: Instructions for operating communication system posted.
children.hint: (NFPA 101 7.2.12.2.6)  Instructions for summoning assistance, via the two-way communication system, and written identification of the area of refuge location shall be posted adjacent to the two-way communication system.

children.title: Verify operation and receipt of visual and audible signals from call box to central control point.
children.hint: (NFPA 72 Table 14.4.3.2(25))   Use the manufacturer’s published instructions and the as-built drawings provided by the system supplier to verify correct operation after the initial testing phase has been performed by the supplier or by the supplier’s designated representative.   Test the two-way communication system to verify operation and receipt of visual and audible signals at the transmitting unit and the receiving unit, respectively.

children.title: Verify voice quality and clarity through call box to central control point.
children.hint: (NFPA 72 Table 14.4.3.2(25))  ...Verify voice quality and clarity.

children.title: Telephone station or jack works properly.
children.hint: (NFPA 72 24.8.11)   In buildings provided with a two-way telephone communications system, at least one telephone station or jack shall be provided at the following locations:   (8)  Area(s) of refuge.   (NFPA 72 Table 14.4.3.2(5d))  Initiate communication path through phone jack.

children.title: Verify call for assistance is sent to constantly attend monitoring
children.hint: (NFPA 72 Table 14.4.3.2(25))  Verify that all remote stations are readily accessible. Verify the timed automatic communications capability to connect with a constantly attended monitoring location.  (NFPA 72  24.10.5)  If the central control point is not constantly attended,it shall have a timed automatic communications capability to connect with a constantly attended monitoring location acceptable to the authority having jurisdiction where responsible personnel can initiate the appropriate response.

children.title: Visual condition of batteries
children.hint: (NFPA 72  Table 14.3.1(9)  Inspect for corrosion or leakage. Verify tightness of connections. Verify marking of the month/year of manufacture.

children.title: Battery 1 load voltage test
children.hint: (Table 14.4.3.2(9))  Battery charger disconnected, terminal voltage measured on max load.

children.title: Battery 2 load voltage test
children.hint: (Table 14.4.3.2(9))  Battery charger disconnected, terminal voltage measured on max load.

children.title: Charger test
children.hint: (Table 14.4.3.2(9))  Batteries connected to charger, measure voltage across batteries.

children.title: Discharge test
children.hint: (Table 14.4.3.2(9(c3))  With the battery charger disconnected, load test the batteries following the manufacturer’s recommendations. Verify the voltage level does not fall below the levels specified. Load testing can be by means of an artificial load equal to the full fire alarm load connected to the battery.
